speaker: thomas
utterance: You know Nugget's little brother got shot Monday.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: No. Is he OK?

speaker: thomas
utterance: He go shot in his stomach and his leg.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: Her little brother? How old is her little brother?

speaker: thomas
utterance: Like 15.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: And what school does he go to?

speaker: thomas
utterance: I don't know.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: So what did you think about it when you heard about it, after you heard about it?

speaker: thomas
utterance: Nothing.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: Nothing?

speaker: thomas
utterance: Just another person got shot.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: Just another person got shot? [SIGH]

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: You can hear it in Thomas's voice, muffled and sluggish, as if he's speaking from deep inside a cave. Even his physical demeanour makes it clear he'd just as well disappear.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: His braided hair hangs over his eyes. He often has a hood on. He won't look you in the eye. Anita's trying to pull him out of his hiding.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Hey, Thomas. What did you think of the memorial for Shakaki?

speaker: thomas
utterance: I walked past it. I don't know.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: Have you looked at it?

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: At the end of October, on the first floor, the school put up a memorial display for Shakaki, the girl Thomas was standing next to when she was killed. It's a glass case filled with pictures of her and her friends, a basketball signed by her teammates, and a note Anita had written to her after she died. Shakaki, who, like so many kids at Harper, half expect to die young, had told Anita if she was killed, she wanted her to put a note in her casket. After she was killed, Anita wrote the note, but you couldn't bring herself to put it in which Shakaki.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Anita had worked with Shakaki for two years. And she's still struggling with their own grief over her death. And partly, it's the shared grief that draws Anita and Thomas together. Like Thomas, Anita hasn't been able to bring herself to look at the memorial.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: Because I haven't looked at it. I saw it. But I could not go up there. I'm not ready to go up there yet. So why haven't you gone up there to look at it?

speaker: thomas
utterance: I don't need to go up there right now.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: OK. I do have a question for you, Thomas. With all of the things that you have experienced, which one is constantly on your mind? You've experienced so much.

speaker: thomas
utterance: I don't think about none of that.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: You don't think about none of it? None of it's on your mind. Not the situation with your brother? What about at the bus stop? What about at the party?

speaker: thomas
utterance: No, I don't think about that.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: You don't think about the party when you were a kid?

speaker: thomas
utterance: Man, I got older. That stuff is old now.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: It's old? You remember what happened, right?

speaker: thomas
utterance: Right, but--

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: Does it really get old, Thomas?

speaker: thomas
utterance: It's done now.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: It's done. I know and I understand that it's done. But does it really get old, where you can say, OK, this is over, I don't think about it anymore?

speaker: thomas
utterance: But if I think about it, I'll do something.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: You'll do something like what?

speaker: thomas
utterance: Try to hurt somebody.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Try to hurt somebody, he says. Trying to hurt someone or wanting to hurt someone, these are things Thomas has said a lot. One time when I asked him where he thought he might be in 10 years, he said, might be in jail, because I think I'm going to hurt someone.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Mostly it felt like tough talk, like teenage bravado. But on this day, when talking about Shakaki, it started to become clear that this kind of talk, talk about hurting someone, isn't just tough guy bragging. I began to realize that Thomas was trying the best he could to be honest about some feelings he has, feelings that scare him. Thomas begins by haltingly explaining what happened the night Shakaki was shot.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: He was standing on the porch, Shakaki next to him. They were just hanging out, just talking. Thomas's brother was in his wheelchair on the sidewalk in front.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: When the shooter, dressed in a gray hoodie, came running up alongside the building, Thomas pleaded with him not to shoot. But the shooter fired several rounds, hitting Shakaki three times and Thomas's brother once in the thigh. Thomas ran but quickly came back. He says that when Shakaki was laying on the ground, he first thought she'd be OK.

speaker: thomas
utterance: Because when she got shot, then anyways, she gonna be all right then.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: She was talking, right?

speaker: thomas
utterance: She was on the ground. She was talking. But all she kept saying, it burned.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: She was saying that it burned. When the ambulances finally showed up, they took Shakaki and Thomas's brother to the hospital, leaving Thomas alone. He didn't go home. He was just alone.

speaker: thomas
utterance: Then they took her. Then they took my brother. Then I walked off mad. I walked to the gas station to see who I could see.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: At the gas station, he didn't find anyone.

speaker: thomas
utterance: And ever since that day, I was just trying to hurt everybody. I didn't sleep that whole week she got killed. She got shot on Saturday. She died Sunday. I was sleepless for a whole week.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: He was filled with grief, anxiety, guilt. And then he got into a fight.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: And what did you get into a fight over?

speaker: thomas
utterance: Nothing important.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Thomas says an older kid on the street pushed his little cousin to the ground. Thomas was furious. He went after the older boy.

speaker: thomas
utterance: It wasn't no fight. I just hit him. And he walked off crying a whole lot. I didn't know his teeth was in my hand until I looked at it.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Thomas punched the boy so hard, one of the boy's teeth got stuck in Thomas hand. Later that night, his grandma took him to the hospital. And he eventually had surgery on his hand.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: He told me that once he hurt his hand, he was able to sleep again. It was that simple. Getting into this stupid fight, it brought him relief.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Thomas has said many times that he knows something violent is going to happen again. It could be random. He says bullets fly all the time.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: One could come through the living room window and hit his grandma. Or a stray bullet could hit Anita when she's on the block. What happens happens, he often says. And when it happens next, he knows he'll need relief again.

speaker: thomas
utterance: If it happens again, I don't think I could stop.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: You're worried that will be the breaking point for you?

speaker: thomas
utterance: No, I ain't worried about nothing. If it happens again, though, I know I could hurt a lot of people if I wanted to.

speaker: anita stewart
utterance: I don't think you want to. I really don't think you want to.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Anita's trying to convince Thomas to deal with his feelings in other ways. Not long ago, they visited Shakaki's gravesite together. Anita says is was big deal for Thomas to go. I'm proud of him, she told me.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Alex Kotlowitz, he'll be back later in our hour.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Act Two, Your Name Written On Us. In the unofficial school calendar for Harper, there are these anniversaries of days that certain kids were shot or the birthdays of those same kids. They have a big enough effect on what happens at school that the administration and the police department keep track of these days. They can be dangerous.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ira glass
utterance: One of the important anniversaries in the fall is TG day, named for Terrance Green. In all kinds of ways since his death at 16, Terrance Green has become one of the iconic figures in the neighborhood around Harper. Ben Calhoun looked into how that happened.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Terrance Green was murdered during summer break, July, 2009. But more than a month later, when kids came back to school, the grief over his death. It was still flooding from the neighborhood into Harper.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: crystal smith
utterance: It was the largest fallout of a student death I had ever seen before. Even the boys couldn't hold back their tears.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Crystal Smith, one of the school's social workers. In some ways, she says that wasn't so surprising. Terrance was popular and charming and funny. But she was still not expecting what she saw next.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: crystal smith
utterance: I started seeing this TGC, TGC, TGC everywhere. Whether it be I was seeing it on book bags or tattooed on one of the kids. And I was like, what is that? And they were like, oh, you know, this is the Terrance Green Crew. It turned into a whole different gang.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: The new clique, the new gang that Terrance's death gave birth to, today it controls 23 city blocks in the neighborhood east of Harper. It's called Terrance Green City, goes by the initials TGC. Sometimes it's called True Gangster City.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: For TGC and two or three other allied gangs, the dates of Terrance's death and his birthday in November, in the neighborhood, those days are a big deal. Hundreds of people turn out for street parties. And around those times, the hostility over Terrance's murder, it can all come back. Crystal remembers last November. The staff was told to clear out of the building immediately when school ended.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: crystal smith
utterance: And they had called in for extra police support. Somebody told me, they were like, they brought the big guns out.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Assault rifles. Some of the police outside the school were carrying assault rifles.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: crystal smith
utterance: But then as I was driving down the street, it was just like a scene I had never seen. I had never seen so many kids posted on the corners at one time. And I had never seen them standing outside with bats and sticks and stuff. And they were, like, on every street.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Three years after Terrance Green's murder, the legacy left by it continues to sprawl. The song you're hearing is just one of the many tributes to Terrance online. There's also slide shows, collages, videos, some with slick editing and production. Lots are on YouTube.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boy
utterance: (SINGING) Yeah, TGC, you already know, man. Young Life, Seven Deuce man. RIP my nigga, man. Prince TG, Prince mother fucka TG. Yeah, we gonna miss you.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boy
utterance: I got you tatted on my arm, man. The grief's still sitting on us, so we got your name written on us. You know how that go.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: The mythology around Terrance and the devotion to him, it's intense. Kids who know Terrance use his last name, Green, in place of their own. This was confusing at first, when I met several of his friends who told me their last name was Green. But the most troubling example of Terrance's legacy was this series of videos made by kids.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: The footage is choppy and grainy, like it's shot on a cell phone. It's of about a dozen kids walking around the street at night. They range in age from maybe 9 or 10 to early high school. Here, they are threatening and taunting a rival gang, S-Dub, which is also called the Dub. It's the gang that's widely believed by students, Harper staff, and police to have killed Terrance.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: girl
utterance: For the rest of my life, I'm screaming, fuck the Dub!

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boy
utterance: Fuck the Dub!

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: girl
utterance: Fuck the Dub!

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Toward the end of the video, one particular kid appears. He looks like he's barely out of middle school, somewhere between 12 and 14. In his right hand is a gun, a semi-automatic.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: He points it at the camera. He shouts hate at opposing gangs. He praises the territory he says he's protecting, Terrance Green City.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: The feud between TGC and S-Dub that followed Terrance's death, it's turned into a long chain of retaliation. Principle Sanders says her staff knows of seven murders and more than 10 other shootings that lead back to Terrance. This list includes Cedric Bell, one of Harper's students killed last year.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: And it's not like Terrance's story is one of a kind. There's other cliques around Harper named after kids who were murdered. There's Bird gang northwest of the school named after Martel Barrett, whose nickname was Bird. He was killed the same year as Terrance. There's Face World, named for a kid whose street name was Face. There's Frank World and Dome City.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: It makes you wonder about the lives of these kids, kids like Terrance. Why did his death lead to songs and kids using his last name in place of their own to assault rifles outside Harper and a remapping of the violence around the school? Why this 16-year-old?

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: tony owens
utterance: This is an eighth grade graduation picture.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: What a cute kid.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Terrance grew up in a house with two loving, hardworking parents. This is his dad here, Tony Owens. He's a full-time bus driver and a union official for the Chicago Transit Authority. His mother, Lorraine Green, works at a bank. Together, the couple raised five kids.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Terrance's siblings, at this point, have all graduated from high school. One's in college. The rest are all doing well. His older brother is a pastor.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: tony owens
utterance: Hey, hey, here's my man, Boogie here.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: How are you doing?

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: It's nice to meet you.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: tony owens
utterance: He's here. Hey man, what's up [INAUDIBLE]?

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: A friend of Terrance's dropped by during one of my visits to Mr. Owens. Boogie was one of the closest people to Terrance. They were friends since third grade. As you're going to hear, there are some big differences in the way they see Terrance's story.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: But here's the stuff they agree on. Terrance was an amazing athlete and a leader. When he was in middle school, he played quarterback for a youth league team that went to a national championship.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: And they both say the problem started when Terrance was in high school. He and Boogie had to walk to Harper through a rival neighborhood. The kids there would bully Terrance and his friends. And then Terrance, he had a teenage fling with and then dumped the little sister of a gang member from the other neighborhood, from S-Dub, the gang that people believe killed him later.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: tony owens
utterance: And she told him that my brother going to get you. She told Terrance that. My brother is going to get you. My brother gonna get you, because he wasn't dating her.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: The way Mr. Owens describes the situation, it was half girl problem, half bully problem. There were some fights in school, some fights on the street. And one Friday afternoon, Terrance got shot in a drive-by. Police reports show the brother was brought in for questioning but was not charged. No one was ever charged.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: And this is where Boogie's version of the story separates from Mr. Owens's on a crucial point. Mr. Owens says Terrance and Boogie and their friend's weren't in a gang. Boogie says that was true, but only at first.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Boogie tells the story this way. When it all started, there was the gang that the girl's brother was in, S-Dub. They were fighting with the older guys in Terrance's neighborhood who were in a gang called Seven Deuce. Boogie has no idea what that war was about-- girls, money, who knows? They'd been at it for years, he says.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: He and Terrance and their friends, they were separate from all that. They were just kids. They were interested in sports and music. They could cross into S-Dub's territory.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: They'd go over, hang out, play basketball. It was no big deal. But by the time they got to high school, it was like a switch flipped on them.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: Once they come through, and we taller now. It's all about height and stuff like that. So they call it hard legs, shooting at any hard legs. That means male-- any male that look of age.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: Any male that look of age will get shot. So that's where it started, right there. You involved now. That's the thing. Now you a part of it.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Boogie says the guys from S-Dub, they just assumed they were with Seven Deuce because they were young men living in the neighborhood. So S-Dub would drive up, point guns at them, threaten them. They'd steal from them and take their stuff, embarrass them in front of girls. It was humiliating.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: And avoiding all that didn't seem like an option. Police or parents or teachers weren't about to step in and fix it. So they turned to each other. They did what a lot of teenage boys might do in that situation. They decided they weren't going to back down.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: One member of TGC tells me Terrance got his friends together for a meeting. He said he was starting something new, a new group. He named it Yung Lyfe, which stood for young, unique, noble gentlemen living youthful and fulfilled every day.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: Fear drove us to really get into it. We felt like we had to fight fire with fire. Like Terrance, he always was a stronger leader because he was the quarterback of a football team. So he knew how to lead a team. So we thought if they want to come burn us down, we gonna come burn they town down, too.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: All this was news to Mr. Owens, Terrance's dad. He never knew that Terrance and his friends were fighting back this way. And when he hears "fight fire with fire," the implication of that, it isn't something Mr. Owens is really ready to accept.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: tony owens
utterance: You know, let me cut in just for a minute. When he say they retaliated off of that, I mean, what can they do? They didn't have no guns. I don't see how y'all could retaliate when you all didn't have what they had.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: They had more power than us. But we had more heart. Terrance had a big heart.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: You can hear how delicate and respectful Boogie's trying to be with his friend's dad. But Mr. Owens insists, you didn't have any guns. And finally, Boogie admits it pretty plainly.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: Yeah, they had things like guns and all type of weapons. But we had the same. We just didn't have as much as them. They had cars and all type of stuff. We were still using CTA.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: It was crazy. But when they got back and forth, when the war really started, if they came on our side, they would have to worry about making it back to their side. And it was the same way for us.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Other friends of Terrance's have told me, by the summer when he was killed, the shooting was pretty much constant. One said, "I'm not going to lie. We were shooting pretty much every day. It was wolf season," he said.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: When they talk about what all this was like, you can totally see why they memorialize Terrance the way they do-- because there'd been this moment when they felt scared and unprotected. He was the one that rallied them. He was their leader. And because he was their leader, he became a target. "He died for us," Boogie told me.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: You can see why they'd want to name their neighborhood after him. Boogie says part of what made those years so frightening for them is that they were underdogs. They were younger, smaller. And they had to figure out for themselves how to fight back. The older guys, the ones in Seven Deuce who'd started the war, they hadn't recruited them. They hadn't taught them how it all worked.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: I'm not blaming it on nobody. But the older guys on our side, they kind of set us up for failure because they let the pressure fall on us. They didn't give nothing to us. But they let the weight fall off onto us. Now it's off of them. All the weight is off of them.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: But now it's our problem. Their problems are our problems now. The weight was put on our shoulders and just dumped.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: Like the older guys, they so separated from us. It's so segregated that we don't even know their names. But they the ones who started the war which led to Terrance getting killed. But I couldn't even recall one of their names if I wanted to.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Of course, to an adult, this is upside down world logic, that the one thing that could have helped them and maybe saved Terrance's life was being recruited and trained by a gang, that the only adults who could have helped them were gang members. And the more Boogie said stuff like this, how they inherited this war, the more upset Mr. Owens got.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: tony owens
utterance: Don't say you was inheriting nothing, because you wasn't. Inheriting means somebody gave you something. And nobody gave you nothing.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: boogie
utterance: And that's what I was saying.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: tony owens
utterance: I'm saying you didn't have nothing to do with what was going on. Y'all was just kids is in hood. Y'all didn't know nothing about these guys. And I never heard this before.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Mr. Owens has lived in the neighborhood since 1986. He thought he understood how the gangs worked. They were organized. They sold drugs.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: You joined, got initiated. You became a bad guy. It was clear who was in them and who wasn't. The world Boogie was describing, where his son was kind of drafted into a gang war he didn't even really want to be a part of, that didn't make sense to Mr. Owens.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Towards the end of our conversation, we looked at a map of that new reality. We looked at the gang map Harper High School uses, where Terrance's initials, TG City, sit on a big rectangle southeast of the high school. Mr. Owen's had never seen anything like it.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: It upset him even more. TG City, he said. He'd always thought that was just a nice nickname the kids had given to the neighborhood, a way of remembering his son, not a gang.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: tony owens
utterance: And that's what you just showed me. I'd never seen it. I never heard it before. I don't like that. I never heard it. I don't like it.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: tony owens
utterance: I don't like it. I do not like that. When you showed me a map of the gang names and TG in that, oh, no. That's his initials. He don't fit in that. He don't fit in that.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: After a few minutes, we walked outside to take a break and get some fresh air. Mr. Owens stood on his porch. He told me a story about how the last time he'd seen Terrance was on his porch. It was morning. Mr. Owens was on his way to work. And he watched as his son walked around the corner to see Boogie and go get a haircut.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Today he stood there, staring at the house kitty corner to his. On one wall of it, there was spray paint that said TGC. Mr. Owen's stared, shaking his head. I don't like that, he said. I don't like that at all.

act_title: Act Two: Your Name Written On Me
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Ben Calhoun.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Act Three, How Kids Get Guns. Chicago's gun control laws are strict. There are no gun shops in the city, no shooting ranges. There's a ban on assault weapons and high capacity magazines.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: But somehow, of course, kids are being shot by other kids. Teenagers can't just walk into a store or a gun show and buy a gun. So how do they get them? The third of our Harper reporters, Linda Lutton, asked.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: I talked to eight Harper students at school one day.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: Can you all come in a little tighter?

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: Most them are freshman, 15 years old. It was often hard at Harper to get kids to talk about how they felt about the violence in their neighborhood. But when it came to something concrete, like where a kid around here would get a gun, it was easy to get into a detailed conversation about dirty guns and clean guns and the prices of each. They said if it's a cheap gun on the street, you have to be careful. It might have a murder on it.

speaker: boy 1
utterance: It'll usually have a murder or something on it.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: And they know how clean guns, guns with no murders on them, end up on the street.

speaker: boy 2
utterance: They got they gun cards. And then when they sell them, they just report them stolen-- like a month later, reported stolen.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: OK, what's the cheapest? Even if it's a dirty gun with a murder on it, what's the cheapest?

speaker: boy 1
utterance: Like $100.

speaker: boy 2
utterance: It depends on what kind of gun it is.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: $100. And what kind of gun would that be for $100?

speaker: boy 2
utterance: Because you gotta trick some people. They would be like, give me $100 for a .22 caliber. Boy, I don't even play with those. What, I'm going to give you $100? I'll give you $25 for it.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: The boys argue for a while over how much a .22 caliber handgun would be worth-- $25, $40, $150, or if it's worth anything at all since it's not a big gun. And who are they getting the guns from?

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: As a kid, how do you know where to go to?

speaker: boy 3
utterance: I go to one of the guys.

speaker: boy 4
utterance: That's what I was going to say, too-- one of the guys.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: What does one of the guys mean? What does that mean?

speaker: boy 2
utterance: One of your friends.

speaker: boy 4
utterance: Well, like for some people, like if you're in a gang or something, you gonna automatically have that. So if you've got connections to a gang, then you gonna have it.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: So how do know who in the gang has the gun?

speaker: boy 4
utterance: We know. We know.

speaker: boy 1
utterance: I've actually made phone calls. If wanted a gun--

speaker: boy 4
utterance: That's what I'm saying, too.

speaker: boy 1
utterance: I could make a phone call.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: Of course, this isn't the most satisfying answer to the question, where do you get your gun? To shrug and say, "from my friends," it doesn't explain how your friends get them. Guns arrive in the neighborhood through all the means you've probably heard of-- straw purchasers, gun show loopholes. The feds recently charged a college student with buying duffel bags full of guns at Indiana gun shows for sale on Chicago streets.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: A University of Chicago crime lab analysis has shown that the biggest proportion of police-recovered guns, around 40%, are purchased legally just outside Chicago, in the suburbs or Indiana. One of the police officers who works at Harper told me $40 or $50 would be a normal price around the neighborhood for a revolver. $100 will get you a semiautomatic.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: But talking to these kids, I realize they often can get a gun for nothing at all. They're free. This kid got two guns from his brother.

speaker: boy 4
utterance: When my brother got it, of course he gonna give to me. Because my brother, he went to jail for a charge. He's still in there right now.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: For a gun charge?

speaker: boy 4
utterance: Yeah. My brother got several guns, though. But the one that he got caught with, they got it. But he got several of them. So I'm going to look at them for him while he in there.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: One kid says he was given a gun by fellow gang members who handed it to him, he says, for having certain rank in the gang. He was 14. Another boy who's backed away from his gang, he moved out of Englewood, says he could still get a gun if he needed it for something, as long as he promised to bring it back. Another boy says his mom has a gun, a legal gun. She keeps it in a box, he says.

speaker: boy 3
utterance: I was 12 when I got my first gun. I was 12. I found it. I saw it. I found it.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: He was near 67th Street, three blocks from Harper.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: Just in the middle of the day, you're going to your grandma's house. And you find a gun.

speaker: boy 3
utterance: Yeah, it was 4 o'clock. And I walked through the alley because I had come up to my grandma's backyard. And something just told me, look down. It was five, six houses down from my grandma.

speaker: boy 5
utterance: People stash guns outside. They don't want their guns in the house.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: All the kids agree, if a gun's in your house, the police can find it in a raid. So people stash them. This one was on the side of the garage.

speaker: boy 3
utterance: It was on the side of the garage like somebody tried to throw it in there while they was running. But they missed or something. It was just laying, not on the garage, on the garbage. You know, the garbages in the alley? It was just laying next to it. And I just picked it up, brung it home.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: The boy kept the gun for a while. Later, because he couldn't figure out how to get any bullets for it and because, he says, he had no use for it, he gave it to a friend. When I asked what type of gun it was, the boy said he was too little to know at the time.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: He only knew it was black. But now that he's older, 15, he does know. It was a .45.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: So where do you keep a gun, if not at home? I'm still not clear on that.

speaker: boy 4
utterance: Abandoned house, I'm going to say that.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: A what?

speaker: boy 4
utterance: Abandoned house.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: What, like next door to you maybe or something?

speaker: boy 4
utterance: Well, not next door to you. I could be like a block or something. But it can't be that far.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: How do protect it, then? How do you know somebody's not going to get in there and get it?

speaker: boy 4
utterance: Because you hide it.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: Well, maybe I live on your block, too, and I'm--

speaker: boy 4
utterance: Well, one of my guys, he had a banger. And he put it in an abandoned house. He put in the basement. And in the basement, they got a little vent. And just scooted it all the way back then just closed. And that's it.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: So if he needs it, he's got it.

speaker: boy 4
utterance: Yeah.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: But it's not on him. It's not in his house.

speaker: boy 3
utterance: You're just close.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: As you'd expect, some guns are more popular than others.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: Do young people want a certain type of gun?

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: What kind?

speaker: boy 3
utterance: A .30, with a long clip-- a clip like this out the gun.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: He's not talking about a specific gun but an accessory, a magazine that holds 30 rounds.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: You like those? Why?

speaker: boy 3
utterance: They got the most shots. You can shoot forever. Let out 15. Run back to where you going. Somebody else come out and let out five more. There you go.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: A lot of these student say they know kids who are only alive because the shooters have such bad aim. That could be another reason why the long clips are popular with kids. It's a good accessory to have when you can't shoot.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Linda Lutton. Coming up, you may remember that teenager who shot his own brother that we talked about in last week's program. We get back to him and what happened to him as the school year progressed. In a minute, from Chicago Public Radio and Public Radio International when our program continues.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: It's This American Life. I'm Ira Glass. This is the second of two hours that we're broadcasting about Harper high school in the Englewood neighborhood of Chicago's South Side. Last year, the school had 29 shootings of current and recent students. We've had three reporters there for five months, starting at the beginning of the school year. We have arrived Act Four of our show. Act Four, Devonte, Part Two.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: One of our reporters, Alex Kotlowitz, spent his time at school in the social work office because that's a place that directly and intensively addresses the effects of the neighborhood's violence on specific students who go to the school. We heard one of the school's two social workers, Anita Stewart, earlier this hour.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Crystal Smith is the other one. Crystal is relentlessly bright, positive, cheerful, peppy-- like, aggressively so. Here's how, early in the year, she says goodbye to a kid in her office who is leaving for class.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: Hello. You are a person, OK. You are valuable. And you matter. Mwah, mwah, mwah. OK, go.

speaker: linda lutton
utterance: By late November this year, though, things have kind of changed. Alex explains how.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: It's the Tuesday before Thanksgiving break. And I run into Crystal Smith who's just coming in to work. She collapses into her chair.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: How you doing?

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: I just got here. I've been battling my brain and just not feeling well since last night. But I'm here.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Since last night? What happened last night?

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: Well, yesterday when I was at work, my whole face became numb. And my lips were tingling. My hand was numb, so I went--

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Crystal tells me that last night she went to the ER. She was worried she was having a stroke. But the doctor told her it was most likely symptoms of stress. But Crystal isn't just having a bad day. Work has been wearing her down. And others, it seem, are having a hard time, too.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: A week earlier, an administrator became so concerned about Crystal that she sent her, along with the school's other social worker and the school psychologist, to a counseling session just for the three of them. She wanted them to begin to process and move past all the crises and the shocks and the funerals they've been through the past year. Crystal and Anita, the other social worker, told me the session was helpful. But they also said it felt sort of pointless.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: "It's not over," they said. Yeah, there haven't been any students killed this year. But the shooting hasn't stopped. I point out that that's how the kids must feel sometimes, and they agree. In the office, I tell Crystal that she looks tired.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: Yeah, I know. Next week, I'll try to be my, you know, ball of energy. I'm going to try. I don't know, maybe your book stressed me out.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Crystal's been working towards a second master's degree, and in one of her classes this year has been reading a book I wrote over 20 years ago called There Are No Children Here, where I follow two brothers living in the projects on Chicago's West Side. For a couple of years, I followed the boys as they grappled with violence, poverty, and the gangs. And Crystal wonders if reading it isn't adding to her stress.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: It was really interesting, though. To think that 20 years later, nothing has changed, that's the scarier part.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: You mean in the neighborhoods?

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: Right. Right. That the same cycles are being repeated over again. OK, now what happened to the cousin, the one with the four kids?

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: She's doing great. Her kids are going off to college. She lives up in Evanston, works in a bank.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: Really? She got out.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Yeah.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: Really. I am so happy to hear that. I needed to hear that. I needed to know that. Wow. I need to see where education works. And I need to see where success happens.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: One of the things that's stressing Crystal out is her relationship with a junior named Devonte. Earlier in the year, Crystal begin meeting regularly with Devonte. I talked about him in last week's show. Last February, Devonte accidentally shot and killed his 14-year-old brother. Since then, his sister has stopped talking to him. And things have been strained with his mom.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Before the accident, Devonte was kind of notorious as a problem kid at Harper. He would curse out the staff. And he hardly showed up for school. But since the beginning of this school year, Devonte's been turning it around.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: He comes to see Crystal sometimes two or three times a day. In spurts, he talks about his feelings, especially his guilt over his brother's death. He's pulled up his grades, getting Bs and Cs in almost all of his classes, the best grades he's ever had in high school.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: So much of this success, I think, has to do with Crystal. For three months, she's let him know he doesn't need to go through this all alone. She encourages him to think about the future he wants for himself. Once when Devonte had stopped by, Crystal had pulled out photographs from a recent vacation she took with her husband in Jamaica.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: And so look, this is part of the resort that we were on. Every morning, you wake up and you see that.

speaker: devonte
utterance: I like that. Almost look clean.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: It is clean. And the water is so blue, you could see all the way down to the bottom.

speaker: woman
utterance: Yes, you can

speaker: devonte
utterance: I don't need to go out there, though.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: You do need to go out there. Look.

speaker: devonte
utterance: The sun is small, isn't it?

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: I know. But I got a better picture of the sunset. I'll bring that later. And I'm going to give you one, because I want you to always make sure that you focused on getting to the sunset. OK? OK.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: So this conversation took place earlier in the fall. Now, today, the Tuesday before Thanksgiving, it seems like Devonte is drifting. Like Crystal and Anita, he just seems spent.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Crystal tells me Devonte's become agitated. He's announced that he's only going to come to school three days a week. I asked Devonte if he'd sit down with me and explain what's going on. I began by asking him about his relationship with Crystal.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: Now, I started getting along with Ms. Smith during sophomore year or something like that. And she started loving me.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: I think she's really fond of you. She worries about you.

speaker: devonte
utterance: Mmm-hmm, all the time. She worries about me all the time.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Do you like it that she worries about you?

speaker: devonte
utterance: Yeah. I like for a person to care for me and stuff.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: I started to ask Devonte a bit about his brother and about the accident. But he told me that he didn't really want to talk about it-- which, you know, fair enough. He told me that he hates memories.

speaker: devonte
utterance: I don't like to think of stuff. I be wanting to give up on my life sometimes.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Is that right, Devonte? Why?

speaker: devonte
utterance: I don't like my life no more. I hate myself.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Why do you hate yourself?

speaker: devonte
utterance: I don't know.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: You hate what happened, right? But you don't hate yourself?

speaker: devonte
utterance: Peoples be looking at me stupid, all the--

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Do people say things to you, Devonte?

speaker: devonte
utterance: Uh-uh.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: So you just think people are looking at you differently?

speaker: devonte
utterance: I see people looking at me other different type of ways.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Do you think Ms. Smith does?

speaker: devonte
utterance: No. And I'm talking about people in my family. I feel that they don't care about me no more. Like if I leave this world, they don't care.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: You think they're angry with you.

speaker: devonte
utterance: I heard my sister say, my little brother go, everybody go, and don't never come back. And I don't want to flip out on nobody. I've been thinking about me just giving up.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: That conversation happened two days before the Thanksgiving break. When I next meet up with Crystal a few weeks later, she tells me that Devonte has stopped coming to school, that she hasn't heard from him. What's worse, though, is that she says she's heard from some of the school staff that he's been picked up by the police on a gun possession charge. Crystal calls Devonte's mom to find out what's going on.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: Hello, can I please speak with Mrs. Grant? Hey, it's Crystal Winfield Smith. How are you?

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: Good, good, good. The police are there looking for Devonte? What?

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Devonte's mom confirms that, yes, Devonte had been picked up on a gun charge, and that earlier in the week went to court for a preliminary hearing. She says that once Devonte heard that he could get locked up for 19 months, he got scared and took off. He literally ran out of the courthouse. He's now on the run. She says she's not sure where he's staying now.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: Crystal knows that Devonte will just get more caught up in the streets, fending for himself, and that at some point the police will get him. And when they do, he's facing serious charges-- the gun charge itself, violation of probation, which he was on for the accidental shooting, maybe running from the court.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: It makes me feel like I lost him. And how could I lose him when I'm reaching my hand out? Grab back.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: A few days later, Crystal calls Devonte. She tells him not to say where he is, so she won't have to lie for him. She then runs through what, for them, has by now become a familiar exercise.

speaker: alex kotlowitz
utterance: When you look in the mirror, what do you see? Crystal asks. The good Devonte, he replies. Then Crystal remind him, don't forget he's in there.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: And so it was very hard for me. And I said, OK, son. I love you. And take care of yourself.

speaker: crystal smith
utterance: And he said, I love you, too, ma. And I hung up. That's that.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Alex Kotlowitz.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Act Five, Reverse Turnaround Backflip. The time of year that we're in right now is hard for Principal Sanders because it's budget time, planning next year's budget. Harper is actually in a good situation this year with money. But as Ben Calhoun explains, that's about to change.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Harper's in a unique spot at the moment because it's what the Chicago school system calls a turnaround school. A few years ago, the system said Harper need an overhaul. So they turned over most of the staff, brought in new people, and infused the school with money, a lot of money.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Just to give you an idea, Harper's total budget this year is $8.9 million. $1.6 million of that is turnaround money. Last year, the turnaround money was even bigger, almost $2 million.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: One former district official involved in Harper's turnaround told me that Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, who used to run Chicago's schools, he said to his former colleagues, with these new turnaround initiatives, like the one at Harper, he wanted to, quote, "take the issue of money off the table," in other words, give them whatever they need. So the plan was pretty much boost the school with a lot of federal, state, and city money, then as the changes took hold, slowly ramp down the money.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: And then five years later, the funding would go back to normal. That's next year. Next year is when the money goes away.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: In the fall, I sat down with Principal Sanders and the school's operations manager to talk about all this. They told me the money has done so much. There's a new culinary learning room, new computer equipment, small stuff like a new ID machine.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Principal Sanders talks about the first year of turnaround like it was amazing. There were four assistant principals, reduced class sizes. There was the kind of support staff-- social workers and counselors-- in numbers that other schools only dream of.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: The operations manager told me he's been a Chicago Public Schools money guy for 15 years. He's been at more than 10 other high schools. He told me he's seen programs like the turnaround program before. It was called other things-- intervention, reconstitution but he says bluntly that Harper is the first time he's seen it work, partly because there's just been more money this time.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: So next year, though, Harper will lose the last $1.6 million of turnaround money, about 18% of its budget. And the biggest effect of that will be layoffs.

speaker: marcel smith
utterance: What's up, [INAUDIBLE]?

speaker: marcel smith
utterance: How you feeling?

speaker: girl
utterance: Good.

speaker: marcel smith
utterance: Hey, Miss Carter. Is that a pass in your hand? I'm so proud of you, Miss Carter.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: What effect will layoffs have on Harper? I spend a couple mornings with a staff member named Marcel Smith. Marcel works on a program that tries to rescue kids who are failing out. Harper has a lot of initiatives like that. There's mentoring programs and enrichment programs, all boosted by turnaround.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: So on paper, that's what Marcel does. But if you walk around with him, you see what Sanders sees, all the little things that would never be considered part of his job. The day I was with him, in the morning, Marcel came across a young man standing in the hallway.

speaker: marcel smith
utterance: What's going on, son? How you feeling?

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: The kid was keeping a straight face. But he was clearly upset. It turned out he'd been asked to leave his class. As Marcel turned to deal with him, he asked me to turn off the recorder, so I did.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: They talked for a minute. Marcel took the kid to his office, sat him down, told him to wait. And we walked away. He didn't want to use the student's name. But he explained what was going on.

speaker: marcel smith
utterance: Apparently, the students were given an incentive for being on time. And it was food.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Cookies. It was cookies. And this student, along with everyone who'd gotten to class on time that day, was allowed to go up and take a cookie. But this particular student was dealing with a difficult and maybe dangerous situation at his house. So he hadn't gone home the night before. And because of that, he hadn't eaten.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: So when he went up to take his cookie, he took two. The teacher told them to put one back. Not wanting to reveal his situation to the rest of the class, he didn't say anything. He just refused.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: He told Marcel he was just so hungry. That's why he'd been kicked out. Marcel had a box of cereal in his office. And I walked with him as he zipped down to the cafeteria. They were out of regular milk.

speaker: marcel smith
utterance: Ladies? Ladies, how y'all doing? Can I get two chocolate milks, please? Thank you.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Back in Marcel's office, the student sat quietly, staring down, and ate a plastic bowl filled with Honey Nut Cheerios and chocolate milk. Then he got up, politely washed the bowl and spoon, said thank you to Marcel, and the two went back to his classroom. You see situations like this all the time at Harper, situations that could so easily unravel.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: And without thinking anything of it, they get addressed because someone is there and makes the effort to figure out what's going on. It's stuff that'll never show up in a school budget. But it can be the difference between a kid going back to class or getting suspended.

speaker: leonetta sanders
utterance: Kids, you know, you can't tell kids when not to have a good day. Like, you can't have a good day on Tuesdays and Thursdays, because I'm not going to be there. You can only have bad days on Monday, Wednesdays, and Fridays.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: This is exactly what Principle Sanders is worried about next year when the turnaround money goes away, the people she'll have to give up. Marcel's position is funded through next year. But he's exactly the kind of person who there won't be money for. Assistant Principal Chad Adams, the school psychologist, numerous teaching positions-- not currently funded for next year. The social workers who you've heard working with Thomas and Devonte-- there's Crystal, and there's Anita-- next year, Anita will go away. And Crystal will only be part time.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Altogether, Harper expects to lose at least a dozen people, about a tenth of the current staff. Two of the security staff who have seen Harper go through overhauls in the past say it always changes when the money is added. But then everything goes backwards once it's lost. There's more fights. The violence gets worse.

speaker: leonetta sanders
utterance: You know, I mean, there's not much we can do. $1.6 million is a lot of money to lose. Every day, I wish I could win the lottery and just pay people out of my pocket.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: When Sanders first said that, it was a joke, not much to it. Except for what Ms. Sanders said then. She told me she does find herself thinking about what she would do if she won the lottery. And a lot of that money, she'd put it into the school.

speaker: leonetta sanders
utterance: I would hook Harper up. And everybody would be sitting back like, dang.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: And then she laid out her plan.

speaker: leonetta sanders
utterance: And I would say, yeah, I mean, they would have the state of the art labs. Every student would have access to a computer. Any of the capital resources, human resources, that we needed, they would have.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: Sanders kept going like this for 4 minutes and 38 seconds. With her imaginary millions, she bought big things, like vacant land near the school. She rehabbed houses where students who are homeless would have a place to stay. She created transportation programs to get kids to and from school safely.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: She did little things. She took a kid who came to school in a hoodie in the middle of winter, and she bought him a coat. She bought detergent for kids who didn't have soap to wash their uniforms. She spent, and she spent. 10 years, she said. She'd structure it out so that the money would be spread out over 10 years.

speaker: leonetta sanders
utterance: So things like that, if I was to win money. It's such a need here. It's just such a need here.

speaker: ben calhoun
utterance: How often do you find yourself budgeting out that imaginary money, that if you had it?

speaker: leonetta sanders
utterance: I do it a lot. [LAUGHS] I do it because every time, it's like a different situation. And I just sit back and say what if? God, what if?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Ben Calhoun.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Act Six, We Are Harper High School.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: marcel smith
utterance: All right, be safe.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Last day of the semester. This is the day that we ended our reporting at Harper. Marcel Smith, saying goodbye to kids who are on their way home.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: ira glass
utterance: I saw that somebody tweeted after our first episode about Harper High School was broadcast. Somebody said that we found the most violent school in America or in Chicago or something. And I just want to say, that is not true.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Nobody keeps statistics like that. We just found a high school-- a high school that's seen a lot of shootings. And there are others.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: liz dozier
utterance: Hi, I'm Liz Dozier, the Principle of Finger High School on the far South Side of Chicago. We've lost nine students to violence in the last little over three years.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: shontae higginbottom
utterance: I am Shontae Higgenbottom. And I'm the new principal here at King College Prep High School here in Chicago. And this year, I've had two students who were shot during our Christmas break. And then we had the last case with Hadiya Pendleton. And she died.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: john lynch
utterance: My name is John Lynch. I'm the Principle of Castlemont High School in Oakland, California. So I've been at Castlemont High School for the past two and a half years. And in the time that I've been here, six students have been shot. And two of those students who were shot were actually killed.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: bertie simmons
utterance: I am Bertie Simmons. And I am the Principal of Furr High School. And it's located on the Far East Side of Houston, Texas. In the last two years, I could name five students that were shot and killed.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: rahel wondwossen
utterance: My name is Rahel Wondwossen. And I am the Principle of Cohen College Prep High School. We are located in Central City, New Orleans. At Cohen College Prep High School last year, we had two students who were shot. Both, thankfully, survived. And in the city of New Orleans, we had more than 10 students who were shot and killed.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: laquanda jackson
utterance: My name is LaQuanda Jackson. I'm the Principle of Simon Gratz Mastery Charter High School in Philadelphia. This year, we have lost one student to gun violence. Last year, we lost two students to gun violence. And the year before, there were six.

act_title: Act Six: We Are Harper High School
speaker: alberto carvalho
utterance: My name is Alberto Carvalho. I am the Superintendent of Miami-Dade County Public Schools right here in Florida. Over the past four and a half years, I have buried or attended viewings for 44 children who have died violent deaths right here in our community.
